metadata.template_skill: Student views two bars with the same number of pieces shaded (numerator > 1, different denominators) and selects the correct comparison symbol

telemetry_data.mastery_skill: Student can select the correct comparison symbol for same-numerator non-unit fractions by comparing piece sizes in bars

steps.dialogue: Look at these two bars. Both have the same number of pieces shaded. Which pieces are bigger?

step.dialogue: Not quite. Look at the size of each individual piece in the two bars.

Let's think about this together. Both bars have 3 pieces shaded, but look carefully at how big each piece is. When a bar is cut into fewer pieces, each piece is bigger. Compare one-sixth to one-eighth - which is larger?

Let me walk you through this. Both bars show 3 shaded pieces, but we need to compare the size of those pieces. The first bar is divided into 6 equal parts - these are sixths. The second bar is divided into 8 equal parts - these are eighths. When you cut the same whole into more pieces, each piece gets smaller. So sixths are bigger than eighths. Since we have 3 of the bigger pieces versus 3 of the smaller pieces, 3/6 is greater than 3/8. When the numerators are the same, the fraction with the smaller denominator is larger.

on_correct.dialogue: Right. Same count, but bigger pieces win.
